Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Deciphering the Neural Basis of a Visual Behavior

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Passaglia 0547457

The research objective of this project is to quantify the computational algorithms employed by the nervous system to convert visual images into a visual behavior. This project on the vision of the horseshoe crab Limulus will provide more knowledge on human vision, nighttime vision and how the brain processes visual inputs. The research will have impact in neural coding, neuromodulation, and computational neuroscience.

The educational component will improve neural engineering education. The educational activities will focus on introducing and disseminating neural engineering material into biomedical engineering education through the development of a teaching simulator, an undergraduate laboratory, and a graduate course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research investigated the neural basis of how animals see at night using horseshoe crabs as a model system. One project recorded and quantitatively analysed the signals sent to the eye by circadian clock neurons in the brain and then electrically stimulated the circadian nerve fibers to determine what signal features are important for communicating nighttime increases in eye sensitivity to light. The main findings were that clock output is complex in organization at night, composed of patterns that repeat on multiple time scales ranging from 0.1s to several minutes. Clock output is also strongly attentuated by just a brief exposure of light at night. Analysis of the activity patterns suggested that they are produced by a weakly-coupled network of clock neurons. Their complexity does not appear to convey information of circadian importance as the number of spikes, and not their temporal pattern, was key to modulating eye sensitivity via electrical stimulation of clock nerve fibers. The complex patterning of activity is presumably then a reflection of the time-keeping mechanism of the clock. The other project expanded the operating range of an existing computer model of the crab eye to include nighttime conditions. The model - the largest and only neural network model that can accurately simulate the output of the eye of a behaving animal - was originally designed for daytime conditions and was modified to include a nonlinear mechanism that is known experimentally to activate at dim light levels. Inclusion of this mechanism produced spike trains resembling those recorded from the crab eye at night, and statistical analysis of model spike trains showed that the detectability of underwater objects was improved at moonlight levels under which crabs often search for mates. Together, these findings have broad relevance to night vision because 1) similar activity patterns are recorded from circadian neurons in mammals but they are not as rich temporally perhaps because they were not collected from  live animals and 2) a similar nonlinearity is seen in the mammalian eye and may thereby be fundamental for seeing in the dark in all animals. 

In conjunction with these research projects, two educational modules were developed and incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses. One module taught basic neurophysiology skills to biomedical engineers using custom-made low-cost setups and horseshoe crabs as an experimental model. Groups of students working in pairs succesfully recorded from optic nerve fibers and then analysed the statistical properties of spike trains evoked by static and dynamic stimuli displayed on a computer monitor. The other module taught computational skills to biomedical engineers using the crab eye model as an instructional tool. Over a three-week period students built the model from scratch by guiding them through physiological experiments upon which the model was based and educating them on how to translate empirical data into mathematical equations and how to then solve those equations numerically. Through these modules students received practical training on how to model physiological systems and in the case of neural systems how to evaluate model assumptions and predictions experimentally, which are skills that define a biomedical engineer.
